abstract.p: A fundamental challenge to the foundations of the discipline of international law, this book offers an internal critique of the discipline of international law whilst showing the necessary place for philosophy within this subject area.

title-group.title: AMERICAN LEGAL CULTURES OF COLLECTIVE SECURITY

abstract.p: I wish to present a perspective from American culture and history, which may help to explain dominant American tendencies to resort to the unilateral use of force to resolve what Americans take to be demands of their national security. This is very far from wishing to deny the importance of international law, either as an intellectual construct or as an ideological weapon. Indeed, the wider cultural, historical analysis is intended to demonstrate the contrary. abstract.p: The predominant anthropology for the place of law in international relations, whether on the side of state sovereignty or international organization, or constitution, has been a radically subjectivist, individualist one.
